text: Hey Zubair
Are you maybe online now?
<@U639Y9AQJ>
yes. finally, we caught each other :slightly_smiling_face:
Great
Are you in for long?
yeah, can be
Or going to work at some point?
Great. So, since this is the last day of the programme, let's go all in with a clear plan if you want.
And maybe talk also about what you believe you want to be doing so that I help even more while offering my advice and mentoring.
yep, that sounds great
So, tell me, what is that you are interested in life more?
career wise?
Career and life in general.
Something that when you do it, time passes and you feel great.
Whether that's singing, going to the gym, dancing, learning a new language.
Anything.
at home - going gym and playing the xbox
At work, its working on a challenging issue where you get to use your braain, but not to the point of stressing about it
Okay, that's great. What kind of games does your gaming involve?
more a preference of how im feeling. Sometimes mulitplayer shooting games, most of the times however, story driven games where its just me
For example, I loved playing strategy games quite a lot myself.
Alright. Like for example Resident Evil type?
Or Zelda?
yeah, those kind of games. (though not that particular one, im a wuss :slightly_smiling_face: )
like Witcher, Mass effect. Games where you build a character and go through everything with him. in a sense
Of course I know. I played games younger as well.
So, relating that to business. You should be considering the way you see this game as the way you need to be resilient.

You need to overcome everything that is going on and always find out ways to complete tasks and projects. And funny enough, since there is a looooot of time that you walk in these games, consider that the time you anyway do things that are mechanical. And take time but have not much value to you, but definitely help to complete projects and tasks.
It's crazy how also games gave me more and more the ability to enhance two of my proud skills.
Can you guess what two skills would games help you to enhance?
I am not grading.
Just want you to participate.
:sunglasses:
i'll give you three: problem solving, persistence/consistent, and team working (in multiplayer when a mic is involved)

Great! So, you know in business jargon, you just said: problem solving, resilience and collaboration. And that's Great, because when you do realize the gains, then you can start applying that to other parts of your life.
For example, have you look through YouTube to maybe get an Excel course like the one I have suggested?
:relaxed:
if im honest, i've not. been too busy looking for jobs locally, as opposed to trying to start developing my skills before i start the job
is excel used in all departments of accounting? My computing background should help somewhat in trying to "excel" in it
Your computing background can help with everything. So, I will explain to you a situation here.
Let's say that you play a game and while you play you realize that you need an object that you found somewhere 3 hours ago in the game to unlock a door to go ahead.
But now you are closer to the door. Than to that object.
Is your next step to try to open the door in another way?
Or go all the way back and get that object?
:thinking_face:
i would go back in this instance. this way, i would be able to breeze from the object to the door less then the 3 hours it took me to get there.
And that's because of a) the need to get the object and b) you would breeze through because of your already experience of doing that route once.
Similarly, if you can see how much you relate to that is that the door is not opening right now.
And what might be the only thing that does not help is a skill.
A skill that might actually just be your ability to sell yourself.
Not necessarily something technical, although in the early career stages the technical skills are the foundation that gives you confidence to sell yourself better and easier.
:slightly_smiling_face:
Can you relate?

See an interesting piece of selling yourself:
<http://www.success.com/article/top-of-mind-on-selling-yourself>

attachments.title: Top of Mind: On Selling Yourself
attachments.text: Confidence is everything when it comes to selling yourself. Knowing who you are and how you can add value is invaluable in any workplace. And it doesn’t mean you are everything or know everything. Confidently admitting you don’t have the answer, while outlining a plan to obtain it, demonstrates a true level of belief in yourself and your abilities. Seize the opportunity to showcase your problem-solving skills.
attachments.fallback: SUCCESS: Top of Mind: On Selling Yourself

text:
And with regards to technical skills, I used Khan Academy for my foundation of my technical skills:
<https://www.khanacademy.org/>

attachments.title: Khan Academy
attachments.text: Learn for free about math, art, computer programming, economics, physics, chemistry, biology, medicine, finance, history, and more. Khan Academy is a nonprofit with the mission of providing a free, world-class education for anyone, anywhere.

text:
This was my favourite place when I wanted to understand my potential in coding and if my brain was actually programmed to do more than economics:

<https://www.codecademy.com/>

attachments.title: Codecademy - learn to code, interactively, for free
attachments.text: Codecademy is the world's most popular way to learn over 12 coding languages including HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, and Ruby. Sign up today and start learning to code in minutes.
attachments.fallback: Codecademy: Codecademy - learn to code, interactively, for free

text: yeah, i used codeacademy. briefly. and khan academy a lot during A-level.
One of the top sites for online learning: <https://www.coursera.org/>

attachments.title: Coursera | Online Courses From Top Universities. Join for Free
attachments.text: 2000+ courses from schools like Stanford and Yale - no application required. Build career skills in data science, computer science, business, and more.
attachments.fallback: Coursera: Coursera | Online Courses From Top Universities. Join for Free

text: going back to earlier, what do you mean by this "Similarly, if you can see how much you relate to that is that the door is not opening right now."

Also one of the top sites for learning:
<https://www.edx.org/>

attachments.title: edX
attachments.text: EdX offers free online courses and classes from the world's best universities and institutions. Explore the latest courses from MIT, Harvard, UC Berkeley, The Smithsonian, Catalyst, The University of Texas and more. Take free courses on your schedule in business, computer science, literature, history, science, engineering, finance, data analysis, statistics and more. Build new skills or pursue a lifelong passion with edX. Learn something new today.

text: So what I meant there was that you effectively have a trouble right now getting through the door.

Either because some companies want a different set of skills, maybe more experience - which means you need to have crossed the root from the object to the door several times and finally maybe they just want you to be more confident when you speak to them.
And sell yourself.
What I did effectively is helped relate your gaming to the actual workplace.
Where the door is a new job
The root is experience
And the object is a skill you miss
:slightly_smiling_face:
ah okay, the explains it. i got confused as to if you were talking about the game or getting through the door in real life.
So ultimately, would you say its a psychological issue?
Let's make you find the answer.
So, what kind of roles do you apply?
Tell me one of them that you got rejected after an interview or two.
Not ones that you did not receive an answer for.

By the way, this is a great resource for free courses from a renowned English University. Loads of free courses and all of them top quality.

<http://www.open.edu/openlearn/free-courses/full-catalogue#>

Im just going for dinner but to quickly answer, most recently, i got rejected from a accounting apprenticeship which was offering CIMA, as mentioned earlier. though im not getting feedback until mid august
No problem. When you are back we can continue then. :-)
So, question. What do you think was the reason for not getting this apprenticeship? Where did you feel this connection did not happen?
im back and ready to get cracking :slightly_smiling_face:
Great.
i feel i failed in the group task. its usually my downfall. I CAN work with other people, but i prefer to get to know them first.
its why rather then having loads of friends, i have s amll circle of close friends.

The presentation i think i aced. and competancy based interviews i do well in, however, the interview i had was strength based. so looking at personallities. And i struggled there due to the facti was trying to base my answers around what i feel they wanted, as opposed to what i wanted.
Great. So, you do know then maybe a weakness of yours in the workplace. Which is hard to actually be stable and safe. And sometimes you need to crack on even with people you might not like at all.
So, you were quite honest about it and what wise men do in this situation?

when i left college, as mentioned previously, aprt from having no expreience (for an entry level position. go figure) was the group task. This was the first one i did since then (2+ years) and spoke a lot more and was generally confident. however, i felt overpowered
work on their weaknesses?
I will help you. An greek ancient philosopher said something once. It's basically a man that does a mistake showed an effort. A man that repeated a mistake is non wiser.
By that, another wise man once said Abraham "Give me six hours to chop down a tree and I will spend the first four sharpening the axe."
Which means that, preparation brings confidence. And since you do have some technical skills, what you might be missing is some leadership course.
Or some real life lessons of the skill you need to get better at.
For example.
We said you are not great at collaborating when you don't know someone.
A friend of mine became great in passing at basketball by going as a freelancer to basketball courts and asking people if he can join their teams.
:sunglasses:

Similarly, although online courses or other course might be Great, maybe you need also a real life experience. For example I volunteered for an anti-drug organisation and had a lot of charity work with them as well.
Lots of difficult people from various backgrounds and more importantly not knowing anyone.
But!! We had a common goal. And that's what you need to find when you are in group tasks.
And if you find it, you need to help guide then the rest of the team through.
That applies to all of the above.
Team in sports.
Team in volunteer activities.
Team in workplace.

(I know I am writing a lot but that's because there are only a few hours left for tonight's cut off time and hope I give you as much as possible and you can then take that and use that in the future and maybe even look at it once you become successful and see how much of that actually related to what you will be doing at that point in time)
na, its fine. Its actually helping me alot
Great. So, next steps. What have you felt is my suggestion so far?
to improve skills that "aren't on paper" eg be more confident in myself, develop skills as a human rather then as a worker
That's one of them. But most importantly is be curious and have a drive.
Try to learn what you need and how to acquire the skill and then go there and acquire that skill.
Any skill.
Amy talent.
:sunglasses:
Believe me, I have so many undocumented skills and extracurricular talents that I acquired because of curiosity that helped me loads in the workplace.
One example is by doing all these things I met a lot of people. Meeting them I also got to understand what they do with these skills.
In the workplace - you always meet that one person passionate about that one thing you did once for a month and never followed.
And that helped me blend in quickly and create a positive atmosphere around me in the workplace.
Having said that, if I were you I would do something quite fun. For example try to acquire 12 different skills.
One each month of the year.
Say, learn the guitar, code in python, learn to speak French, cook different types of food, etc.
Trust me. The confidence you start to build and the personality change will not go unnoticed.
On top of that, never forget the basics. For which, being still good with job, keeping a healthy life with the gym and also working on your financial skills are and should be your bread and butter.
Before anything else, everyone will ask you your Microsoft Excel skills to be great. Not your guitar playing. So, to step through the door - you need to be great at Excel.

I think with this job being on the other side of the country, and me being isolated from friends and family, i will initially have enough time to leearn something. Being a supporter of FC Barcelona, spanish has always intrigued me
but i get what your saying, keep your mind engaged with things other then work, but know that, first put your foot in the door by learning said work skills.
:wink:

See this:
<https://youtu.be/5MgBikgcWnY>

attachments.title: The first 20 hours -- how to learn anything | Josh Kaufman | TEDxCSU
attachments.fallback: YouTube Video: The first 20 hours -- how to learn anything | Josh Kaufman | TEDxCSU

text: This explains how easy you can actually become good and why not very good at something with not that much of an effort as some people think.
And the road to skill mastering.
It's from TEDx
And I have always loved watching their videos.
okay, about yourself then. because i dont think i know enough about you, what is your official title? what qualifications do you hold?
I am a Commercial Finance Manager
I lead a part of a company's financials.

Which means that I am responsible to understand what type of discounts consumers get, what type of investment do supermarkets that will have our products get, what are the costs to produce the product, costs to store it, transfer it and any duties for imports or exports and if that's not enough, the investment in advertisement and marketing behind that product.

So, basically I am the curious guy involved in the whole process trying to make things happen bit making sure that they happen for the good of both the consumer and my company to still be able to pay people's salaries and make a profit for the people that support the company through their investment in it.
Qualifications. I have a bachelor's degree and two masters.
I have several years working in different jobs.
CIMA would have made my life easier a few years ago. But now I don't need it as much as I am already ahead of what CIMA could help me achieve.

Having said that. As I lead by example, I started a few weeks ago to actually attend CIMA classes. I aim to complete it next year. Just to make sure I am able to knock confidently the next door. Maybe that of the Finance Director of the company.
:slightly_smiling_face:

(For reference, when I say I lead by example, I mean I don't just suggest to you that you need to acquire and employ more skills in your life - but I also do what I suggest. By still enhancing my current ones and working on the bread and butter or foundation.)
Since there is now only a limited amount of time left before the platform closes, I would be very keen to answer any questions you may have still on your career plan and path.

whats the work life like? id imagine being a manager, its more then just 9-5? Is the job as boring as people say it is? can you see an exit plan, though, i feel with the amount of years youve been in this game, its not a question you ask yourself these days?
I do ask myself questions everyday. That's part of my mentality on how to become better or change myself to adapt to a situation.
Work life is relevant to your goals and aspirations.
Initially in the early stages - you build.
And when you build there is so much information around you that you want to embrace it.
By doing so, I accelerated my effectiveness and progress within a role and a company.
For that, the price I had to pay is extra hours of work.
At later stages though, as your learning curve becomes more smooth and is not as steep, you then give more time to other priorities.
For example now I work sometimes (like today) less hours per day that 9-5
The reason is my boss has built confidence that I will contribute my best to compensate for the time I did not put today and also confident I will get the job done right.

Experience teaches you that doing things right is not the only thing that matters. But doing the right things is as well. So yes, by also deciding what I want to do with my career, I directly impact the time I spend sometimes in the office d.
in the beginning though, did that mean a sacrifice of your social life?
My exit plan is simple. Be able to create my own venture and support it throughout all of each stages with my own funds.
Yes and no.
As I am very social, I just made my social life different.
For example I took longer breaks to talk with different people in different departments.

And although it's not great to stay 2, 3, 4 or more hours at work, I did make myself feel human and created some good networking opportunities as people move around and maybe you can meet them again in future endeavours.
before you started working though, and during rather, you attained 3 qualifications and are studying right now. So would you say the work ethic was ingrained into you from the beginning?
Yes. My mother and father worked VERY hard when I was a child.
I grew up mostly with one of my grandmas and grandpas
So, yes. A lot of hard work myself, a lot of working on the foundation to be able to then build on a career path with less worry and more confidence.
I am a very adaptive and resilient person and I am driven by my curiosity and energy.
okay, finaly question (i think). hopefully, you've got some vague idea of me as a person/thinker. So, am i entering the right field here?

That's for you to decide. You definitely have some of the values we need in finance. But no one but yourself will know that better. Since finance will always be a very changing environment and your maths are good but not incredible to do for example engineering, then definitely accounting will make you feel comfortable.
You need to consider taking a few courses on Microsoft Excel for accountants. By doing so, you will see if you enjoy some of the technical part of the job.

After that, this job keeps me happy because I am curious. And I ask questions. For example I ask questions on why this product, why this machinery to make it, why this advert to promote it, why this price.
And for all these, numbers come to make it easy to take a decision.
So, the question is, are you ready to invest your time for the procession to pay back later? If So, then definitely you are in the right route if you like numbers as well.
As a person I can see that although you are young you do have some good communication skills and can step back from a situation to reflect on what you are doing right and wrong.
That's a great trait to have.

I always thought IT was the one for me, as working on the computer was like second nature, it didn't pan out quite the way i was hoping, and so the 18 months for working weren't as...efficient. So going into a completely different field, im in 2 minds as to whether to take the risk.
I know how you feel.
But
working in financial services also caught my eye, atleast the investments area. But again, i dont think my skills would blend well there as well as it does here, no9 matter how minor
No, investments is not what I would think it's the right place to be. Unless you are willing to sacrifice many more hours than what you believe is enough.
Combine your IT background and learn Excel.
Use it for accounting and finance.
And then use it to quantify simple things.
Like everyday decisions you take on what to buy based on what's on offer.
It's as simple as I say it.
Right now, I know you are confused.
And feeling that this is a big risk.
But trust me. The biggest risk is the one to not take any risk at all.
And since you are sub 30, you are far too young to think that you cannot reverse anything.
At this point, anything can be used in the future as learning and experience building.
One thing only to remember is that mistakes only need to happen once. Then learn from them and not repeat them.
So, risk and if you win great. But if you lose, learn. This way you will win in the future.

its like that great Michael Jordan quote: I've missed more than 9000 shots in my career. I've lost almost 300 games. 26 times, I've been trusted to take the game winning shot and missed. I've failed over and over and over again in my life. And that is why I succeed.
He made me be a fan of the game of basketball and was my personal inspiration during junior high school.
:slightly_smiling_face:

its like in football now. Whilst Messi is the :goat: he was naturally talented, and being a fan of Barca, it would be automatic for me to not like Ronaldo. Away from what people think of his personality, hes a great role model because he got to (near) the top due to hard work. And so anyone can excel with dedication.
Exactly!
And based on that, what do you feel should be your next steps?
to go for it!

until now, ive been looking for other jobs, postponing the reality of moving away from my comfort zone (as you mentioned). But, with just over a month to go until the start date, its time I went head on.
Great.
The next year is going to be monumental in my life. I will be independant and in a job in which ill have a good knowledge of where i will be
Learn more, work hard, socialize and build relationships that are positive, keep being healthy and see how next year is only the start.
Never forget to build relationships that are positive.
It's crazy important to avoid negative comments, backstabbing, participating in gossip, etc.
Build relationships based on healthy habits, positive news and ideas and you will see how this will turn around in your favour in the future.
It's a low cost high returns investment if we speak the Finance language

one thing about me is that i always try to shake off negativity. I feel emotions like a normal human being, but i never let them affect me. so hopefully, this trend will stay and i will be able to make connections for life.
Great. And if you want some inspiration - visit TEDx
It will make you expand your ideas. Develop more your cognitive biases and definitely help you be positive in life with all the stories shared there being great stories.
before i let you get on with your life, is there anything you'd like to ask me?
Yes. How do you feel after our literally two intense sessions?
great. It took a while to get going due to schedules, but it was definetly worth it.
And what do you think I should be doing differently with other people? Say for example I have more mentees looking for help in the future.
Or people that work for me.
and by schedules, its me being rubbish at time keeping
What do you think I need to change or work on?
ooh. tough questions.
Feel free.
In life when you don't know, say I don't know. Don't fear saying I don't know.
But if you do feel you know, share the help.
:slightly_smiling_face:
maybe open up more, personally. Like, try to get a connection going away from the work-life. for example, i only knew you like basketball/MJ after i brought it up near the end
Good point. I didn't indeed manage to open up as much.
Do you feel that this would have made the connection easier?
Or make you feel more comfortable that I share more of my personal stuff?
yes! a lot easier. A mentor is essentially a buddy, and what good is a buddy if you dont actually know them
Nice. That's a great way to look at a mentor.
Thank you for that as well and I hope you now do have a clear path to success.
but apart from that, you were really insightful, so i cant really fault you anywhere else.
Whether that's success through achievement or success through learning after a failure.

before i go, i forgot to ask, how would a career in data science work? its a very sought after job in todays technological world. I would need to be a data analyst before i get there, but that was was the 3rd string tugging at me
Ha
Interestingly enough, data science is not my best skill.
but their i go again, caught in different minds
Having said that, if you have the intellectual curiosity to learn to interpret data - you will manage your finance development faster than your peers.
So, keep that intellectual stimulation as is.
Just work on getting actually some of those skills going
alright thanks.just had to get it in there quickly :slightly_smiling_face:
No problem. That's why I am here for as well.

to sign of (again), Genuinely, you have been a HUGE help. I honestly can not thank you enough. I would love to keep in contact with you on Linkedin, and you'll get to see if i follow through with the job. Who knows, we may even meet each other at a convention or something (if accountants have them)
Please, do. Michail Besis is my name.
I am happy to watch you grow and thrive.
It has been a great experience for me as well. I am sure that this has also helped me become a different person. Even for a little bit. So thank you for your time as well.
Have a great evening, a great weekend and a great time. And come Monday, get your sleeves up and start investing in your future.
:sunglasses: :sunglasses: :sunglasses: :sunglasses: :sunglasses: :sunglasses: :sunglasses: :sunglasses: :sunglasses: :sunglasses:
:basketball:
yes sir :slightly_smiling_face:
Fantastic. That said. Good night Zubair!
ive sent the invite, ill be the handsome one :smile:
good night
